Review Revisiting aluminum current collector in lithium-ion batteries: Corrosion and countermeasures Shanglin Yang Jinyan Zhong ⁎ Songmei Li ⁎ Bin Li ⁎ Key Laboratory of Aerospace Advanced Materials and Performance of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science & Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing 100191, China Key Laboratory of Aerospace Advanced Materials and Performance of Ministry of Education School of Materials Science & Engineering Beihang University Beijing 100191 China Key Laboratory of Aerospace Advanced Materials and Performance of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science & Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing 100191, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract In this review, the corrosion failure behavior of the cathode aluminum current collector in lithium-ion batteries with organic electrolytes is comprehensively analyzed, and the corresponding protective strategies are systematically summarized. With the large-scale service of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), their failures have attracted significant attentions. While the decay of active materials is the primary cause for LIB failures, the degradation of auxiliary materials, such as current collector corrosion, should not be disregarded. Therefore, it is necessary to conduct a comprehensive review in this field. In this review, from the perspectives of electrochemistry and materials, we systematically summarize the corrosion behavior of aluminum cathode current collector and propose corresponding countermeasures. Firstly, the corrosion type is clarified based on the properties of passivation layers in different organic electrolyte components. Furthermore, a thoroughgoing analysis is presented to examine the impact of various factors on aluminum corrosion, including lithium salts, organic solvents, water impurities, and operating conditions. Subsequently, strategies for electrolyte and protection layer employed to suppress corrosion are discussed in detail. Lastly and most importantly, we provide insights and recommendations to prevent corrosion of current collectors, facilitate the development of advanced current collectors and the implementation of next-generation high-voltage stable LIBs. Keywords Lithium-ion battery Aluminum current collector Corrosion Electrochemical performance Electrolyte Protective layer 1 Introduction Energy is a pivotal driver for advancing social and economic progress. However, the challenges of energy supply stemming from reliance on conventional fossil fuels and their unsustainable environmental impact have raised widespread concerns [1,2]. Hence, the development of clean new energy coupled with efficient energy storage holds immense significance. As a vital technology for energy storage and release, the advancement of batteries propels the progression of energy conversion and electrification [3]. Since the successful commercialization in the 1990s, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have supplanted traditional lead-acid batteries due to their superior energy density, extended lifespan and low self-discharge, remaining a vibrant field of scientific inquiry and industrial application [4–6]. Currently, LIBs are extensively utilized in portable electronic devices and increasingly serve as the primary power source for electric vehicles (EVs), leading to a global market capitalization up to $32 billion in 2020 [7–9]. The explosive growth of EVs is significantly impacting lithium reserves [10,11], with China accounting for nearly half of the global stock and registrations of EVs over the years (Fig. 1 a and b). To cater to this burgeoning market demand, there is an urgent need for LIBs with higher energy density [12,13]. And as batteries undergo repeated cycles of charging and discharging based on reversible insertion, their maximum stored and provided power inevitably diminishes over time. The possibility of abrupt malfunction necessitates a higher level of battery durability [14]. Along with these policy orientations, the development of LIBs focuses on enhancing electrochemical performance while ensuring the stability of battery components, which is a crucial factor in delaying aging or failure [15]. A comprehensive understanding of the degradation mechanism of components involved in operation is essential. The failure of LIBs is a complex interplay among various degradation mechanisms, rather than a singular phenomenon [16,17]. And the algorithmic model FMMEA (failure modes, mechanisms, effects analysis) proposed in 2015 predicts multiple risks associated with this process, as illustrated in Fig. 1(c) [18]. Previous studies have primarily focused on optimizing electrodes and electrolytes based on the severity of component degradation-induced failure [7,19–23], with less emphasis placed on the corrosion of cathode aluminum (Al) current collector [24,25]. This is attributed to the conventionally recognized stability of Al under operational conditions. However, the gradually rising cut-off voltage and even the harsh ambient temperature render the corrosion of Al in organic electrolytes for LIBs increasingly noteworthy [26]. Concretely, with the increase of potential or long-term service, corrosion occurrence induces debonding between Al and active material, thereby limiting battery power. The accumulation of corrosion products increases the contact resistance at the interface, resulting in a capacity loss. Severe corrosion can even lead to a short circuit, posing a safety hazard [27–29]. Therefore, addressing the corrosion issue of Al current collector can effectively enhance battery performance, prolong lifespan, bolster safety and promote sustainable development. Referring to the Scopus database, the corrosion of Al has assuredly garnered escalating scientific attention in the deployment of high-voltage LIBs. The number of publications on this topic exhibits a growth trend similar to that of studies on electrode materials, highlighting the research potential (Fig. 2 a). Based on the time path diagram (Fig. 2b), researchers have been investigating the anode behavior of Al current collector in various organic electrolytes since 1997, followed by implementing corrosion inhibition through adjustment of electrolyte composition. Throughout this exploration, a variety of corrosion mechanisms (including different types and processes) have been proposed. And since 2012, the protection of Al through artificial passivation layers has emerged as a prominent research topic, with ample opportunities for further exploration in the development of advanced anticorrosion Al current collectors on the horizon. Hence, it is evident that the corrosion concern of Al in organic electrolytes has been closely linked to the commercialization of LIBs. However, despite advancements in battery technology and sophisticated applications, a deeper understanding of this issue remains elusive beyond mere experiential knowledge and systematic overview. This review article delves into the corrosion of Al current collector in LIBs systematically, as depicted in Fig. 3 . The corrosion process of Al in organic electrolytes is determined by the passivation layer. Eventually, localized corrosion occurs due to the breakdown of this protective layer. The corrosion mechanism is elucidated in a step-by-step manner by considering the influence of various factors on the properties, such as composition and solubility, of the passivation layer. As the bottleneck for the next generation of high-voltage LIBs, an increasing amount of research has been conducted on corrosion inhibition based on its underlying mechanism. These protective measures are categorized and assessed in order to provide insights and inspiration for more innovative initiatives. 2 Corrosion mechanism of aluminum current collector 2.1 Passivation layer and corrosion process The service environment of Al current collector in LIB is an organic electrolyte, which mainly consists of various lithium salts, solvents and additives [30]. In this system, the standard electrode potential of Al (1.38 V vs. Li/Li+) is much lower than the operating voltage of the loaded cathode active material (3.5 V vs. Li/Li+ or even higher) [31–33]. Therefore, the corrosion of Al in LIBs is a thermodynamic oxidation decomposition process as the anode of a galvanic cell, while the corresponding cathodic process involves reduction reactions in organic electrolytes [34]. Fortunately, the natural passivation layer of Al2O3 (with a thickness of 5 nm) on the surface of Al foil largely compensates for the electrochemical instability of pure Al (up to 3.8 V vs. Li/Li+). This efficaciously overcomes the adverse thermodynamic factor and provides kinetic stability (Fig. 4 a) [35–37]. However, the widened operating voltage window of Al2O3 is still limited. Once the critical voltage value in an organic electrolyte is exceeded, the passivation layer faces deterioration and corrosion begins [38]. At present, the corrosion model is well defined, with the key lying in the solubility of Al-complexes (AlF3, Al(TFSI)3, etc.) generated in situ through the interaction between Al2O3 and organic electrolytes [39–41]. The specific corrosion process is described as the following successive steps. First, the anion/solvent diffuses from the bulk electrolyte to the Al electrode (Eq. (1)). And the natural Al2O3 generates Al3+ adsorbed on the surface of current collector under the action of electrochemical force (Eq. (2)). This adsorbed Al3+ serves as an intermediate component, continuously participating in the subsequent reactions. (1) anion/solvent(sol) → anion/solvent(ad) (2) Al2O3 → 2Al3+ (ad) + 3/2 O2 + 6e− As a strong unstable Lewis acid, Al3+ tends to further form complexes with diffused lithium salt anions or solvent molecules (Eq. (3)). And the reaction occurs preferentially on highly active spots of Al surface film due to machining or crystal defects. Complementally, Eq. (3) is used here solely as a general formula, while detailed chemical reactions for various lithium salts are described in Section 3.1. (3) Al3+ (ad) + anion/solvent → Al-complexes(ad) At this point, the subsequent corrosion process is determined by the solubility of Al-complexes in organic electrolytes as mentioned above. Concretely, the insoluble AlF3 formed on top of Al2O3 in traditional LiPF6 electrolyte is a new component of passivation layer, which further passivates Al current collector and broadens the operating voltage window to a certain extent, as shown in Fig. 4(b). While the soluble complex accelerates the breakdown of passivation layer in lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)amide (LiN(FSO2)2, LiFSA or LiFSI) electrolyte, Al(FSA)3 continuously desorbs and then diffuses into the bulk electrolyte (Eq. (4)) and Fig. 4c). In particular, the dissociation of Al(FSA)3 is significantly inhibited in highly concentrated electrolytes without free solvent (Fig. 4d), and Al3+ also dissolves slowly compared to dilute electrolytes [42]. The Eq. (2) proceeding leads to the accumulation of interfacial Al3+ due to untimely diffusion, causing a shift in chemical equilibrium to the left and enhancing the stability of passivation layer. (4) Al-complexes(ad) → Al-complexes(sol) It can be seen that the durability of Al current collector is reflected in the stability of passivation layer as voltage continues to rise. The AlF3 passivation layer has an insufficient thickness (approximately 1 nm) and the local current density is uneven, so that the accidental breakdown under long-term operation or at high voltage can still induce corrosion [43]. And the formation and solvation of Al(FSA)3 continuously damage Al2O3, causing the chemical equilibrium of Eq. (2) to shift forward until the fresh Al substrate is exposed to more intensive oxidation. Regardless of the composition of passivation layer, once protection fails in any area, the Al matrix comes into direct contact with the electrolyte to form Al3+, and Al3+ diffuses into the bulk electrolyte, exacerbating current collector corrosion (Eqs. (5) and (6)). (5) Al → Al3+ (ad) + 3e− (6) Al3+ (ad) → Al3+ (sol) 2.2 Corrosion type After clarifying each step of the corrosion process, it is indicated that Al foil can resist uniform corrosion well due to the existence of a natural oxide layer [44]. The preferential adsorption of solvent molecules and anions by highly active spots on the current collector surface, as well as the subsequent reaction steps, confirm that the corrosion type must be localized corrosion. 2.2.1 Pitting corrosion Electrochemical methods, such as cyclic voltammetry (CV), can be used to evaluate the electrochemical stability of Al foil in organic electrolytes, while the corrosion morphology can be directly observed with scanning electron microscope (SEM). Emphatically, the potential that current density begins to increase abruptly in CV curve is pitting potential (E p) [44]. In LiPF6 electrolyte, the oxidation peak of the first cycle is attributed to the inevitable oxidation of electrolyte and the formation of AlF3 passivation layer. And the decrease of anode current density in subsequent cycles further confirms the considerable protection of AlF3. However, the slight decrease in E p and the sudden step of current density in the fifth cycle indicate the local breakdown of passivation layer (Fig. 5 a). While in lithium bis(trifluoro-methanesulfonyl)imide (LiN(CF3SO2)2, LiTFSI) electrolyte, the current density of reverse scanning is consistently higher than that of positive scanning, and the peak current density increases with each cycle, indicating that Al has not been effectively passivated, and the corrosion is aggravated by the formation and solvation of soluble Al(TFSI)3 (Fig. 5b). The phenomenon revealed by CV curves is consistent with the corrosion process proposed in Section 2.1. And intuitively, it is judged that Al foil suffers pitting corrosion by the holes and scars on the surface of current collector (Fig. 5c and d) [43,45]. Further considering that Al current collector loads active materials during actual operation, the surface of transition-metal oxide exhibits stronger electrolyte oxidation compared to Al2O3, resulting in a higher concentration of HF or F−. Yoon et al. [32] prepared a special LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 (LNMO) electrode with a central digging hole to expose Al. The corrosion behavior of Al in the presence of active materials was discussed, and the corrosion morphology was explained by an ion diffusion mechanism, as shown in Fig. 5(e). The cation (Al3+) dominated outward diffusion leads to a void at Al/passivation layer interface, and the continuous growth of this cavity causes breakdown of passivation layer, forming a pit. And the predominant anion (F−) inward diffusion induces the fluorination of Al2O3, resulting in a larger volume expansion due to the smaller density of AlF3, and cracks are formed when the top tensile stress exceeds the fracture toughness. Invariably, the ion diffusion still occurs at specific position such as grain boundary. The local accumulation of erosive particles deteriorates the passivation layer on the current collector surface, thereby inducing pitting corrosion [46]. 2.2.2 Crevice corrosion Al exhibits corrosion resistance in LiPF6 electrolyte due to the protection of AlF3 within a certain potential range, but the corrosion still occurs on the expected intact Al after assembling cathode materials. In view of this, another localized corrosion model is proposed. Generally, the cathode material is intentionally made porous with a high specific surface area to facilitate better electrolyte infiltration. Therefore, Al foil must have a certain number of microregions exposed to the electrolyte due to the porosity of the cathode. When electrolyte is trapped in a microscopic crevice between the current collector and the porous cathode, underdeposit corrosion occurs, which is a type of crevice corrosion (Fig. 6 ) [37,47,48]. In other words, the crevice corrosion mechanism focuses more on the properties of current collector after participating in tests of LIBs, rather than solely considering the electrochemical corrosion behavior of Al in electrolytes. Zhang et al. [48] expounded the susceptibility of Al to crevice corrosion based on the anodic behavior of Al coated with LiFePO4 (LFP) or LiMnO2 (LMO) in LiPF6 electrolyte. Particularly, the selected operating voltage is much lower than the critical value for irreversible oxidation or significant catalysis of the electrolyte by the cathode active material. That is, the fundamental cause of corrosion lies in localized excess accumulation of HF within microscopic crevices, resulting in the concentrated depletion of Al2O3 beneath the deposit layer and eventually leading to the breakdown of passivation layer or even exposure of Al. This adversely affects the long-term operational lifespan of batteries and results in a loss of capacity. And the corrosion morphology exhibits characteristics of pits with some cathode particles. Hence, it can be observed that the crevice corrosion of Al current collector is dependent on both the shape of crevice and the corrosiveness of the solution in microgap. Summarily, no matter what type of corrosion it is, the similarity is the accelerated localized corrosion caused by the rupture of passivation layer. However, the factors that interfere with this process are extremely complicated. To clarify the corrosion behavior of Al current collector, the next section discusses each influencing factor individually. 3 Factors affecting passivation layer and corrosion behavior 3.1 Lithium salts Lithium salt guarantees the ion conductivity of LIB. The properties of different lithium salts limit the applicability of electrolytes and also affect the corrosion behavior of Al current collector. An increasing number of lithium salts have been designed and explored, representing the evolution of anions. Lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6), lithium perchlorate (LiClO4), lithium hexafluoroarsenate (LiAsF6) and lithium tetrafluoroborate (LiBF4) all have anions comprised of ligands around a central atom. While the anions of lithium bis(oxalato)borate (LiBOB) and lithium difluoro(oxalato)borate (LiDFOB) are based on organic ligand. Complex anions with sulfonyl groups are a comprehensively studied category, including lithium trifluoromethanesulfonate (Li(CF3SO3), LiTf), lithium bis(trifluoro-methanesulfonyl)imide (LiN(CF3SO2)2, LiTFSI), lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiN(FSO2)2, LiFSI), or lithium bis(perfluoroethanesulfonyl)imide (LiN(C2F5SO2)2, LiBETI) [49,50]. As described in Section 2.1, the effect of lithium salts on corrosion behavior is related to the formation of the passivation layer resulting from the reaction between its anion and Al2O3. In the following, we categorize lithium salts based on the passivation ability of their anions in low-concentration electrolytes for Al current collector, as depicted in Fig. 7 . 3.1.1 Anions forming insoluble passivation layers (1) Anion comprised of ligands around a central atom (e.g., PF6 −) Compared to LiBF4, LiClO4 and LiAsF6, LiPF6 is the most widely commercialized nowadays [36,38,39,51]. Although LiBF4 has lower moisture sensitivity, better thermal stability, and superior passivation of Al than LiPF6, it is eliminated due to its low ionic conductivity [52,53]. ClO4 − cannot form a protective film on Al surface, and the highly oxidative Cl (VII) may easily react with organic compounds, making LiClO4 impractical for industrial use [36,54–56]. Additionally, if the toxicity is not a concern, the combination of cathodic and anodic stability would have made LiAsF6 a promising candidate salt [54]. The dominance of LiPF6 in organic carbonate-based electrolytes is not reflected in the extreme of a single feature, but rather provides the best balance among all properties for batteries, especially regarding relatively higher ionic conductivity (1 M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate (EC/DMC): 10.8 mS cm−1) [57]. In fact, the poor thermal stability and high moisture sensitivity of LiPF6 seriously limit the operating temperature range of batteries (15–35 °C) and produce highly reactive HF, involving multi-stage reactions [58]. The decomposition of LiPF6 is shown in Eq. (7), and the initial reaction temperature under a dry inert atmosphere is 107 °C. (7) LiPF6 → LiF + PF5 Complementally, the impact of Eq. (7) is negligible at room temperature, however, in battery electrolytes, the interaction between PF5 and solvent molecules such as EC and diethyl carbonate (DEC) can shift reaction equilibrium to the right [58]. Subsequent degradation occurs due to the exposure to traces of water, moisture or alcohol impurities as stated in Eq. (8) and Eq. (9). (8) PF5 + H2O → POF3 + 2HF (9) PF5 + ROH → POF3 + RF + HF HF interacts with the natural oxide layer on the Al surface to form AlF3 (Eq. (10)), and the H2O generated in this process further participates in the hydrolysis of LiPF6 (Eq. (8)) [59]. Furthermore, HF is actually considered to play key role in the formation of a flexible solid electrolyte interface (SEI) on Li metal. The chemical structure of passivation layer was confirmed by CV and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The fluorination layer is not an additional layer, but rather a transformation in composition at the top of pristine Al2O3 [32]. As depicted in Fig. 8 , the low fluorine content in pristine Al is attributed to the residual cryolite (Na3AlF6) from current collector production, while a distinct AlF3 signal is observed after an extended period of high-voltage cycling. Summarily, the inevitable hydrolysis of LiPF6 salt in impurities promotes the formation of AlF3, which effectively delays corrosion failure by re-passivating the Al current collector to a certain extent above approximately 4.2 V vs. Li/Li+ [37,60]. The role of HF in this process is considered as a ‘favorable’ component, contrasting with the adverse effect caused by excessive accumulation in microcrevices mentioned in Section 2.2.2. It is evident that the role of HF should be viewed dialectically. Complementarily, AlF3 is the key component of the passivation layer, while other equilibriums allow for the detection of LiF and others as well. (10) Al2O3 + 6HF → 2AlF3 + 3H2O (2) Anion based on organic ligand (e.g., BOB−, DFOB−) As a salt with a boron-based anion, LiBOB (LiB(C2O4)2) possesses relatively high ionic conductivity (7.5 mS cm−1 in EC/DMC), primely stabilizes the SEI on the surface of graphite anode, and exhibits remarkable overcharge tolerance. However, its limited solubility in linear carbonate leads to a correspondingly high viscosity, and the SEI formed with LiBOB is highly resistive, which is disadvantageous to the power/rate capability of batteries, especially at low temperatures [53]. BOB− also has passivation ability, but the protective species is obviously different from PF6 − and BF4 −, which is attributed to the absence of F in its chemical structure [61]. With the electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance (EQCM) measurement, Zhang et al. [62] determined that the chemical combination of Al3+ and B-O molecular moieties forms an AlBO3 protective layer. And in the presence of trace water at high anodic potential (around 5.3 V vs. Li/Li+), the decomposition of LiBOB also generates B2O3, as shown in Eq. (11) [59]. (11) 2LiBOB + 4H2O → B2O3 + Li2O + 8CO2 + 8e− + H+ LiDFOB, which combines the advantages of LiBOB and LiBF4, was proposed to optimize ionic conductivity (4.4 mS cm−1 in EC/DMC) over a wide temperature range and effectively passivate Al at high potentials [53,63]. Similarly, the passivation of Al by LiDFOB also combines the effects of B-O and F with Al3+. It can be seen that as the anodic potential increases, lithium salts with passivation ability interact with natural oxide to form a passivation layer, thereby elevating the voltage window of Al to some extent. Moreover, these lithium salts are also considered feasible as electrolyte additives in Section 4.1.1, where they are discussed as one of the protective strategies. 3.1.2 Anions forming soluble Al-complexes In this category of lithium salts, LiTf has the simplest anion, while imide-based salts with two x-fluorosulfonyl (x = 1–5) groups such as LiFSI, LiTFSI or LiBETI have been successively proposed. Their remarkable thermal and chemical stability towards active materials and water is considered as possible substitutes for LiPF6 [49,64,65]. However, the common issue with these salts is Al corrosion (>3.5 V vs. Li/Li+) caused by their low-concentration carbonate electrolytes, although a proper electrolyte solvent or additive can be applied to alleviate it [44,66–69]. As described at Section 2.1, the anion adsorbed at a local defect reacts with the released Al3+ from Al2O3 surface and forms a soluble corrosion product, which diffuses into the bulk electrolyte, resulting in the breakdown of natural oxide layer. The crux of these anions is that when the voltage threshold for Al2O3 protection is reached, the subsequently formed soluble complex cannot achieve re-passivation of the current collector. Instead, they continuously deplete Al3+ until fresh Al is exposed. Taking LiTFSI as an example, the specific corrosion process is presented by Eqs. (12)–(14) and Eqs. (5) and (6), in sequence [40,70,71]. And the depth profiling of Al etched by argon ions (Ar+) further supports this perspective, as evidenced by the observed compositional changes across different layers of the interface (Fig. 9 a and b) [72]. No effective protective layer, except for Al2O3, was detected on Al surface after potentiodynamic polarization. And the atomic concentration of metal Al gradually increases with longer etching time. The content of fluorine and carbon always approaches zero with the distribution of depth, indicating that the initial signal is likely caused by surface contamination. (12) N(CF3SO2)2 − (sol) → N(CF3SO2)2 − (Al) (13) N ( C F 3 S O 2 ) 2 ( A l ) - + A l 2 O 3 → [ A l ( N ( C F 3 S O 2 ) 2 ) x ] ( A l ) 3 + x - + O 2 + e - (14) [ A l ( N ( C F 3 S O 2 ) 2 ) x ] ( A l ) 3 + x - → [ A l ( N ( C F 3 S O 2 ) 2 ) x ] ( s o l ) 3 + x - In another mechanism, Nakajima et al. [57] attributed corrosion to the reduction of the surface oxide layer by CF2 and carbon atom generated through electrochemical oxidation of anions, as described in Eqs. (15)–(19). (15) CF3SO3 − → CF3SO3 + e− → CF2 (16) 2CF2 → C* + CF4 (17) Al2O3 + 3C∗ → 2Al + 3CO (18) Al2O3 + 3/2C∗ → 2Al + 3/2CO2 (19) Al2O3 + 3CF2 → 2Al + 3COF2 In particular, superconcentrated electrolytes are effective in suppressing Al corrosion. However, their wide application in industry is hindered by the higher cost and viscosity associated with them [73–75]. The progressive inhibition of anodic Al dissolution with increasing salt concentration is intuitively demonstrated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) of Al and the subsequent SEM observation (Fig. 9c). Obvious scars and pits are present on the surface of current collector in diluted solution [76]. Notably, the protective mechanism of this concentration effect is controversial. Matsumoto et al. [42] proposed that the dissociation constant of LiTFSI at high concentration is so low that TFSI− cannot interact with Al3+, but F− generated by the oxidative decomposition of TFSI− interacts with Li+ at high voltage to form a thick LiF passivation layer, as shown in Fig. 9(d). However, Ar+ etching in XPS measurement can also lead to the decomposition of residual TFSI−, casting doubt on the reliability of LiF as evidence. The elimination of uncoordinated (free) solvents in the electrolyte is more acceptable [76,77]. First-principle density-functional-theory-based molecular dynamics (DFT-MD) verifies that there are no freely solvent molecules in the high- concentration LiFSA/acetonitrile (AN) solution (Fig. 9e) [41]. In this case, the formation of Al-complexes(ad) in Eq. (3) is quite sluggish, and the solubility of formed Al(FSA)3 is extremely low because all solvent molecules are already in a Li+-solvating state. The high concentration of anions at the Al/electrolyte interface also serves as a barrier, hindering the access of solvent molecules to Al and preventing the loss of material (dissolution) from Al surface. Therefore, the corrosion of Al is significantly delayed in a high concentration of lithium imide salts. The corrosion behavior is also influenced by the structural effect of lithium imide [78]. The larger anion size of BETI− makes it more difficult for the nitrogen center atom of imide anion to attack active spots on Al surface [40]. Among the Li salts mentioned so far, the stability of Al with respect to oxidative potentials was found to increase in an order of LiTf < LiTFSI < LiBETI < LiPF6 < LiBF4. The choice of a certain lithium salt may confer high antioxidation on Al current collector, but it may also sacrifice other properties, prompting researchers to explore the formulation of blended-salt electrolytes [79,80]. Furthermore, the ongoing research and development of new lithium salts necessitates considering their impact on current collector corrosion, which ultimately determines the feasibility of forming a protective passivation layer. 3.2 Organic solvents The type and molecular structure of organic solvents, as well as their interaction with lithium salts, can alter the equilibrium of the aforementioned corrosion process, resulting in variations in the anodic polarization behavior of Al current collector. And generally, the research of solvent effect on the corrosion behavior of Al current collector is mostly based on lithium salts that lack re-passivation ability due to the decomposition of natural oxide layer, such as LiTFSI [81,82]. 3.2.1 Esters The prevailing category of solvents for commercial LIB electrolytes is still carbonate esters, including linear (DMC; DEC; ethyl methyl carbonate, EMC) and cyclic (ethylene carbonate, EC; propylene carbonate, PC; vinylene carbonate, VC) [83]. They exhibit an appropriate viscosity ranging from 0.5 to 2 mPa s and possess excellent solvating capability towards most Li salts [30]. And owing to their high dielectric constant (e.g., EC: ε = 89), carbonate solvents show superior solubility to initial corrosion products (Al(TFSI)3) in low-concentration electrolyte, which accelerates corrosion. While in high-concentration electrolyte, the solvation of coordination with Li+ delays corrosion [40,44,84]. Additionally, it is worth noting that an organic solvent with a high dielectric constant can effectively shield the charge surrounding metal ions, thereby reducing charge interactions. Consequently, Al(TFSI)3 readily dissociates in solvents with a high dielectric constant, leading to an increase in solubility. Indeed, the solubility of Al-complexes in low-concentration organic electrolytes is also influenced by additional factors, including temperature, pressure, and other co-solvents. Considering that our subsequent discussions revolve around the impact of changing solvents on corrosion, the dielectric constant of different solvents is regarded as the primary characteristic affecting the solubility of Al-complexes. Furthermore, inspired by Eq. (3), the fluorinated ester is expected to promote the formation of aluminum fluoride-based passivation layer as a fluorine source. The addition of fluorine atoms increases the viscosity of electrolyte, but it also offers obvious advantages, including reduced flammability, improved flash point, and enhanced electrochemical stability [72,85]. Kawamura et al. [86] changed the solvent of LiTFSI/EC + DMC to methyl difluoroacetate (MFA), and the corrosion potential increased from 3.7 to 4.45 V vs. Li/Li+. This increase is attributed to the low dielectric constant of MFA, which reduces the solubility of Al(TFSI)3, while also generating AlF3 through the contribution of F structure. Similarly, ethyl (1-fluoroethyl) carbonate (F1DEC), 1-fluoroethyl (2,2,2-trifluoroethyl) carbonate (F4DEC) or 1,1,1,3,3,3-hexafluoropropan-2-yl N,N-diethylcarbamate (F-C4) were also applied as solvents or co-solvents to inhibit the corrosion of Al in LiTFSI-based electrolytes [72,87,88]. 3.2.2 Ethers Thanks to the combination of moderate dielectric constant, high electron donicity and denticity, ethers (e.g., 1,3-dioxolane, DOL; dimethyl ether, DME; tetra(ethyleneglycol)dimethyl ether, TEGDME) generally possess low viscosity and high solvating power. However, in sharp contrast to esters, ethers are typically much more volatile and flammable. Additionally, due to inherent interfacial shortcomings at both cathodes and anodes, ethers have been less successful in commercial LIBs, and their intrinsic antioxidative chemical instability naturally limits their application in any high-voltage (>4 V) cathode materials [30,89]. Zhang et al. [44] found that the E p of Al corrosion in EC/DME (1:1, w/w) electrolytes was approximately 3.2 V vs. Li/Li+ regardless of the type of Li salts used, which was much lower than that observed in carbonate solvents. Although LiPF6 or LiBF4 restrains the subsequent increase of current density, the partial substitution of carbonate with ether in the solvent still increases corrosion sensitivity. Yang et al. [36] changed the solvent of LiTFSI electrolyte from PC to poly(ethylene glycol) dimethyl ether (PEGDME) from the viewpoint of reducing the solubility of Al(TFSI)3. In order to broaden the voltage window of ether-based electrolytes without corroding the Al current collector, high concentration electrolyte (HCE) and fluorinated ethers are effective strategies [90–92]. Jiao et al. [89] found that the NMC cathode remained stable in a highly concentrated LiTFSI-LiDFOB/DME electrolyte under a cut-off voltage of 4.3 V, and there was no excessive oxidation of the ether solvent. The significant improvement in oxidation potential can be attributed to the exceedingly limited presence of free ether molecules, the lower oxidized tendency of ether molecules bonded with Li+, and the low solubility of the reaction product Al(TFSI)3. But inevitably, the high cost and viscosity of HCE limit their practical application. Fluorinated ethers can form a stable fluorine-rich cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) film on the cathode to resist oxidation under high potential. However, they hardly solvate Li+, which poses a challenge in combining high-voltage stability with high Li+ solvation ability in a single molecule. Zhao et al. [93] reported a new solvent 2,2-dimethoxy-4-(trifluoromethyl)-1,3-dioxolane (DTDL) to solve this dilemma, and the E p of Al in 1 M LiFSI/DTDL electrolyte was raised to 5.5 V. Generally, fluorinated ether is commonly used as an inert diluent to reduce the viscosity of HCE without damaging solvation structure, thereby inducing the formation of a stable localized high-concentration electrolyte (LHCE) [94,95]. Furthermore, it must be acknowledged that there is still insufficient research on fluorinated ethers as solvents, particularly regarding the corrosion and stability of Al current collector in ether-based electrolytes. 3.2.3 Sulfone-based solvents Sulfone-based (e.g., dimethyl sulfite, DMS; ethylmethyl sulfone, EMS; methoxyethylmethyl sulfone, MEMS) electrolytes with low cost and a wide electrochemical window (>5 V vs. Li/Li+) have a promising application in high-voltage batteries. Generally, sulfone-based solvents can be classified as cyclic or acyclic in structure and also as symmetric or unsymmetric based on substituent groups [96]. Sulfolane (SL) and/or organic sulfites are used as solvents or additives in electrolytes for LIBs. Unfortunately, the relatively high melting point and viscosity in comparison to organic carbonates are still detrimental drawbacks [97–99]. Hirata et al. [100] investigated the passivation behavior of Al in a LiFSI/SL electrolyte with a medium concentration (1.5 M). The CV curve exhibited a similar anodic behavior to that of conventional LiPF6 electrolyte. And the XPS results suggested that the inorganic passivation layer contains both LiF and sulfurous species, which are formed through the oxidative decomposition of LiFSI. Moreover, the dielectric constant (ε = 43.4) of SL makes it difficult to form complexes with Al3+. Unexpectedly, Alvarado et al. [101] observed obvious pitting on the Al current collector separated from LNMO/graphite cell after long-term (1000th) galvanostatic cycling in a 3 M highly concentrated LiFSI/SL electrolyte. This result challenges the established notion that LiFSI-based electrolytes with a high concentration are able to mitigate Al corrosion. This is not a complete denial, but the reaction kinetics are sufficiently suppressed to the extent that corrosion cannot be observed in CV or short-term service. To ease the corrosion of SL-based HCE, Ren et al. [94] introduced a non-solvating fluorinated ether (TTE) diluent into concentrated LiFSI/SL to form LHCE, which enabled the stable cycling of a Li/LNMO battery with high coulombic efficiency at 4.9 V. Dialectically, the surface reaction of cathode materials and species generated at CEI may also affect corrosion, and further investigation is still required to understand the physical background of LHCE behavior. To promote the application of LHCEs in advanced high-voltage LIBs, it is necessary to explore the anodic stability of novel electrolyte composition and the properties of Al interface. 3.2.4 Ionic liquids The low-melting salts, which consist of a large cation and a flexible anion, tend to be liquid at room temperature or below. These salts belong to a new category of liquids known as room-temperature ionic liquids (RTILs), or organic-type room-temperature molten salts [96]. As new promising solvents or additives, ILs possess remarkable physicochemical properties including great thermal stability, non-flammability, exceptionally low vapor pressure, a wide liquid-phase temperature, and high antioxidation under high potential (above 5.3 V vs. Li/Li+) [102–105]. Unfortunately, two or three orders of magnitude with higher viscosity than that of carbonate-based organic solvents are still the drawback [106,107]. Common anions, including TFSI−, FSI−, BF4 − and PF6 −, have different effects on the solubility of Al corrosion products when combined with various cations such as quaternary ammonium, imidazolium, pyrrolidinium, piperidinium salts, hexyltrimethyl phosphonium or triethylsulfonium salts. Moreover, in practical application of LIBs, due to the limited electrochemical stability of certain RTILs in achieving the reduction potential of lithium or lithium-carbon, additives are incorporated to form a SEI that inhibits the electrolyte decomposition on the negative electrode. Peng et al. [102] replaced EC + DMC in LiTFSI electrolyte to a series of 1-alkyl-3-methylimidazolium bis[(trifluoromethyl)sulfonyl] amide RTILs (EMI-TFSI, PMI-TFSI and BMI-TFSI), resulting in the disappearance of Al corrosion. Instead, clusters of insoluble solid products were observed on Al surface, which consisted of precipitates forming the passivation layer (with amide compounds as the main components). And the mechanism still involves a decrease in the solubility of the Al-TFSI complexes in these ILs. While Peng et al. [103] found that Al formed a passivation layer dominated by Al2O3/AlF3 in 1 M LiBF4/BMI-BF4 electrolyte. However, it is worth noting that the anions of ILs and lithium salts are identical in these cases. Cho et al. [108] investigated the passivation behavior of Al in LiTFSI dissolved in N-methyl-N-propyl-pyrrolidinium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (PMPyr-FSI) with a smaller anion size. The anodic current density rapidly increases above 4 V vs. Li/Li+ and becomes larger in subsequent cycles, indicating a localized breakage of the passivation layer and the formation of pits. The reaction between FSI− and Al2O3 is more active than that of TFSI−. Al(FSI)3 is soluble in this IL and cannot form a stable passivation layer, which accelerates corrosion. Further addition of a small amount of LiPF6 counteracts corrosion by forming AlF3, and it also improves the cyclic stability of Li/LiCoO2 (LCO) battery (Fig. 10 a–f). Wongittharom et al. [79] also proposed an electrolyte formula consisting of 0.4 M LiTFSI and 0.6 M LiPF6 in butylmethylpyrrolidinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (BMP-TFSI), which avoids pitting at 50 °C and improves the rate capacity and cyclic stability of Li/LNMO cells at 4.7 V compared to conventional organic electrolytes. Similarly, ILs can also be combined with carbonates to balance the viscosity and conductivity of electrolytes, while improving the electrochemical stability of Al in imide-based salts at room temperature or higher [106,109]. Liang et al. [110] utilized a novel IL-based electrolyte composed of LiTFSI, (N-propyl-N-methylpiperidiniumdifluoro(oxalato)borate (PP13DFOB) and DMC. The higher highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy value of DFOB− than other molecules makes it a better electron donor for preferential oxidation, resulting in the formation of a dense passivation layer of B-O/B-F compounds (Fig. 10g–h). In summary, the properties of ILs are determined by their chemical structure, which includes cations (the type of central atom, substituents, and side chain length) and anions (organic or inorganic constituents). Furthermore, combining them with other types of solvents can optimize electrolyte compositions. Importantly, the solubility of corrosion products decreases when ILs and lithium salts have the same anions, which is more conducive to passivating Al current collector. And additional inhibitors can further improve the corrosion resistance at elevated temperatures. 3.2.5 Nitriles At present, nitriles are considered promising co-solvents or additives, with their content in most electrolytes being approximately 10% V/V or lower [111]. And according to the number of cyano groups, the nitrile family can be classified into solvents based on mononitriles and dinitriles [96]. Furthermore, it has been confirmed that dinitrile-containing electrolytes exhibit a wide liquid temperature range and high anodic potential. But they are thermodynamically unstable at low potential, meaning that the reduction of nitrile solvents cannot form stable SEI on carbonaceous anodes, especially on graphite, which needs to be alleviated by adding FEC, VC or EC [112]. Notably, it is undeniable that nitriles contribute to the anticorrosion of Al. The E p of Al in LiTFSI with solvents containing a cyano group is about 4.15 V vs. Li/Li+, rather than experiencing severe corrosion at 3.7 V vs. Li/Li+. Cyano groups passivate the current collector surface through the lone pair electrons on the nitrogen atom. Censo et al. [113] found that the addition of AN, methoxyacetonitrile (MeOAN) or methoxypropionitrile (MeOPN) all enhances the corrosion resistance of Al in 1 M LiTFSI electrolyte. And it seems reasonable to suspect that the reductive polymerization of the cyano group occurs on the Al surface to form a product layer. Condensed nitriles can adsorb onto Al or slowly diffuse from it, which partially hinders the adsorption of erosive anions. Moreover, based on this mechanism, nitrile functionalized disiloxane and silyl ether have also been proved to be beneficial for stabilizing high-voltage LIBs [114,115]. So far, the various organic solvents mentioned in Section 3.2 possess distinct advantages and disadvantages based on their own physical and chemical properties, making them suitable for corresponding application scenarios. While from the perspective of the electrochemical behavior of Al, the influence of different solvents on corrosion is manifested in the solubility of corrosion products and their potential to form a protective layer through specific chemical structures. And it is essential for researchers to strike a balance between properties, cost, and the corrosion resistance for Al current collector when selecting solvents. 3.3 Impurity of water Water has a detrimental impact on the performance of LIBs. Electrically active water negatively affects most active materials and electrolytes, thus minimizing moisture in batteries is crucial. However, it is undeniable that the existence of trace water is beneficial to the formation of AlF3 passivation layer in LiPF6-based electrolytes, which helps stabilize the Al current collector [116]. Hence, it is critical to analyze the source and content of water in LIBs. 3.3.1 Utilized water during cathode manufacturing Generally, the cathode processing is typically based on the use of fluorine-containing polymers (e.g., poly(vinylidene difluoride), PVDF) as binders for electrode preparation and toxic and teratogenetic N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) as a solvent/dispersant [117–119]. Hence, eco-friendly water-based processing is gradually being applied on a large scale, but it may also cause Al current collector corrosion [120]. Prior to complete drying of the electrode coating for battery assembly, the water-based slurry interacts with Al. And even after the drying process, water contamination persists in porous cathodes, anodes, separators and electrolytes. The natural protective layer of Al2O3 remains stable within a pH range of 4.5 to 8.5. However, the highly alkaline pH (>10) of water-processed cathode slurry leads to localized breakdown of the Al2O3 surface [117,121]. Furthermore, partial hydrolysis of certain cathode materials can be employed to further elevate the pH value of water-based slurry. At high pH, water-soluble Al species such as Al(OH)4 − and AlO2 − are formed, which may interact with the cathode active material during the cathode processing of LIBs. Additionally, the solid byproducts of corrosion may increase interfacial electrical resistance, while their soluble counterparts may induce electrolyte contamination. The specific reactions that may occur are illustrated in Eqs. (20)–(22). (20) Al2O3 + 3H2O + 2OH− → 2Al(OH)4 − (21) Al → Al3+ + 3e− (22) 6H2O + 2OH− + 6e− → 8(OH)− + 3H2↑ 3.3.2 Residual water in assembled batteries Trace amounts of residual water are inevitable in assembled batteries due to material processing and manufacturing technology, with a typical specification of less than 50 ppm [122,123]. And the presence of water contamination in battery assembly results in a reduction in capacity and an increase in internal resistance of LIB, particularly when using the water-sensitive LiPF6. The proposal for the formation of an AlF3 passivation layer by LiPF6 with the assistance of trace water has been presented in Section 3.1.1. Generally, the interaction between LiPF6 and water can be summarized by Eq. (23). In reality, the process is more intricate. And considering Al corrosion resistance and even battery longevity emphatically, the pivotal step lies in the formation of a menacing HF [124]. (23) LiPF6 + 4H2O → H3PO4 + LiF + 5HF The hydrolysis kinetics are described in detail below [125,126]. LiPF6 has an equilibrium with its ions and molecular dissociation compounds (Eq. (24)). The strong Lewis acid PF5 rapidly reacts with water, as depicted by Eq. (25). The concentration of PF5 and POF3 intermediates in carbonate-based electrolytes is exceedingly low (∼9 ppm POF3 in 1.0 M LiPF6 in EC/EMC). The water content differential determines the subsequent reaction stage of POF3 (Eqs. (26)–(28)). If the moisture content is minimal, the further hydrolysis kinetics of HPO2F2 are significantly hindered, resulting in HPO2F2 and HF being the primary hydrolysis products of LiPF6. In this case, an AlF3 passivation layer generated by the reaction between HF and Al2O3 (Eq. (10)) can partially resist current collector corrosion, while a trace amount of water is considered a ‘favorable’ component for LiPF6-based electrolyte. (24) LiPF6 ⇌ Li+ + PF6 − ⇌ LiF + PF5 (25) PF5 + H2O → POF3 + 2HF (26) POF3 + H2O → HPO2F2 + HF (27) HPO2F2 + H2O → H2PO3F + HF (28) H2PO3F + H2O → H3PO4 + HF However, sulfonate-based salts (e.g., LiTFSI) are insensitive to water and do not undergo hydrolysis. As expounded in Section 3.1.2, a stable re-passivation layer cannot be established on the surface of Al in low-concentration electrolytes with these salts, rendering the electrochemical stability of the current collector itself largely unaffected by water contamination in assembled batteries. 3.4 Operating condition 3.4.1 Cut-off potential The anodic dissolution (corrosion) of Al current collector is closely associated with the high anodic potential limit during the charging process and electrochemical procedures. Different cut-off voltages are implemented at the end of galvanostatic charge period of LIBs, depending on the type of cathode materials. Certain cathode materials, such as LFP, LiV2O5, and LMO, exhibit a low potential for lithium intercalation (3.0–3.3 V vs. Li/Li+), which is below the threshold of Al2O3 protection at around 3.8 V vs. Li/Li+, thereby eliminating risk of current collector corrosion. However, other cathodes necessitate higher positive potential limits. LCO and NMC layered materials undergo Li+ deintercalation at approximately 4 V vs. Li/Li+, whereas some olivine (LiCoPO4, LiNiPO4) and spinel materials (LMNO) operate in close proximity to 5 V vs. Li/Li+ [127]. It is evident that increasing the cut-off potential to accommodate high-voltage cathode materials undoubtedly benefits the enhancement of LIB energy density, yet it also imposes higher demands on the electrochemical stability of Al current collectors. Once the cut-off potential exceeds the stable upper limit voltage of the passivation layer on Al surface in current system, corrosion becomes an inevitable factor contributing to battery life decay. As described in Section 3.1, the stability of Al current collector is influenced by various electrolyte salts, and the formation of insoluble complexes facilitates adaptation to higher cut-off voltages. Similarly, altering solvents or incorporating additives can enhance the corrosion resistance of Al. Therefore, it is imperative to establish a reasonable cut-off potential based on electrolyte composition and cathode materials. Moreover, applying an artificial passivation layer on Al surface is also a viable approach to enhancing electrochemical stability. Further elaboration on Al corrosion protection will be discussed later. 3.4.2 Temperature The optimal temperature range for LIBs is 15–35 °C. Any deviation from this comfort zone results in a temperature effect. At lower operating temperatures, batteries exhibit sluggish chemical reaction activity and charge transfer rate. While the effects of high temperature are more extensive, as they involve not only elevated operating temperatures but also internal temperatures that exceed ambient conditions during high current states, leading to a decline in battery performance [128,129]. The temperature restricts various components of battery, including electrolytes, anodes, cathodes and interfaces [130]. Therefore, it is important to emphasize that our primary focus here is solely on the influence of temperature on the anodic behavior of Al current collector. In a corrosive galvanic cell, the anodic reaction of Al involves the conversion of Al to Al3+. According to the Arrhenius equation Eq. (29), the temperature dependence of reaction kinetics is reflected in the rate constant K, meaning that an increase in temperature promotes anodic dissolution. The Butler-Volmer equation reveals the kinetics of electrochemical corrosion (Eqs. (30) and (31), simplified to a single-electron reaction). Where E a represents activation energy, j 0 denotes exchange current density, α/β stands for reduction/oxidation transfer coefficient, F is the Faraday constant, R is the universal gas constant, T represents absolute temperature, η a /η c refers to anodic/cathodic overpotential, φ a /φ c indicates anodic/cathodic potential and φ corr is corrosion potential (equilibrium potential) [34]. In addition, other temperature-dependent factors such as the solubility of corrosion products, the properties of passivation layer, and the diffusion limitations of half reactions further influence corrosion kinetics. (29) K = A e - E a RT (30) j a = j 0 e β F RT η a - e - α F RT η a , η a = φ a - φ corr (31) j c = j 0 e α F RT η c - e - β F RT η c , η c = φ corr - φ c Moreover, the impact of temperature on corrosion thermodynamics can be elucidated by means of Nernst equation (Eqs. (32)–(34)). Where φ 0 is standard electrode potential, n is the number of electrons, and a refers to the chemical activity of oxidized/reduced species. The low concentration of Al3+ makes a Al 3 + a Al much less than 1. As the temperature increases, the logarithmic term becomes more negative and φ a decreases, leading to an aggravation of corrosion. (32) φ cell = φ c - φ a (33) φ a = φ a 0 + RT nF ln a Al 3 + a Al (34) φ c = φ c 0 + RT nF ln a O x a R y Concretely, Gabryelczyk et al. [131] utilized the Taguchi method to comprehensively analyze Al corrosion in relation to temperature, solvent volume ratio, and lithium salt type. The results indicate that the chemical structure of lithium salt has a primary influence on corrosion/anodic dissolution, while temperature plays a secondary role. However, as the temperature increases, the resulting changes in Al corrosion gradually become significant, which is closely linked to the thermal stability of lithium salts mentioned in Section 3.1. For LiPF6, the stability of P-F bond is compromised at temperatures exceeding 60 °C, leading to the formation of highly reactive PF5, a potent Lewis acid that readily interacts with organic solvents (Eqs. (35)–(39)) [132]. Furthermore, the presence of trace water exacerbates thermal instability through hydrolysis. Typically, the decomposition temperature of LiTFSI with extremely high thermal stability reaches 360 °C. However, LiTFSI is limited to high-voltage applications due to its inability to passivate Al current collectors. Meister et al. [133] addressed this issue by combining IL Pyr14TFSI and LiTFSI, effectively restraining pitting corrosion even at 60 °C. Undeniably, this assumption relies on the thermal stability and passivation ability of the electrolyte component towards Al.In LiFTFSI-Pyr14FTFSI, an expansion in pit size on the current collector surface was also observed as temperature increased (Fig. 11 ). Hence, based on a plethora of studies, it is evident that elevated temperatures have an adverse effect on corrosion resistance of current collectors [80,133]. Nevertheless, judicious selection of lithium salts or solvents can ensure both the thermal stability of electrolytes and the anticorrosion property of Al at high temperatures. (35) CH2OCOOCH2 + CH2OCOOHCH2 + PF5 → -CH2CH2OCOO-CH2CH2OCOOPF5 → Oligo-ether carbonates (36) C2H5OCOOC2H5 + PF5 → C2H5OCOOPF4 + HF + C2H4 (37) C2H5OCOOPF4 → POF3 + C2H4 + HF + CO2 (38) C2H5OCOOPF4 + HF → PF4OH + C2H5F + CO2 (39) C2H4 + HF → C2H5F 3.5 Properties of active material coating As stated in Section 2.2.2, Al current collector is subjected to porous cathodic electrode coating under actual operating conditions, and the locally exposed micropores are recognized by some scholars as the preferred position for crevice corrosion. The thickened electrode coating increases the active material load along with the increasing energy density of LIBs, and may also reduce the matrix exposure to stabilize Al. However, this comes at the cost of significantly reduced Li+ transport dynamics [134]. Additionally, the catalytic properties of cathode materials may induce oxidative decomposition of electrolytes, resulting in the erosion of Al surface by generated products [135]. Hyams et al. [136] confirmed that Al, when covered with porous cathodes of LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.5O2, is susceptible to significant crevice corrosion in 1.2 M LiPF6 in EC/EMC. This electrolyte formula was supposed to be favorable for stabilizing Al, but corrosion still occurs due to the random exposure of Al microregions. Wang et al. [137] compared the corrosion behavior of Al with varying loadings of LNMO (thickness of 15–20 and 55–60 μm). The thicker active material enhances battery coulomb efficiency while also providing greater resistance to erosive particles reaching the surface of Al. Currently, there is insufficient research on how electrode coating properties (such as coverage, thickness and porosity) affect the corrosion of Al current collectors. Moreover, cathode chemistries exhibit variations in terms of thermal, chemical, and electrochemical stability as well as decomposition pathway and rate. Corrosion products may also react with cathode materials, exacerbating the aging of LIBs. Therefore, further investigation is required to address these issues. After considering the aforementioned affecting factors, it is evident that the properties of passivation layer remain crucial in determining corrosion behavior. The solubility of passivation layer is regulated by various electrolyte components, including anions, solvents and concentration. Furthermore, operating parameters (temperature and cut-off voltage) not only prioritize safety and high energy density but also adhere to boundary conditions that ensure the stability of both the passivation layer and electrolyte. Clarifying the mechanism by which corrosion factors is beneficial for implementing effective corrosion protection, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance of LIBs. 4 Countermeasures to inhibit corrosion Under actual operating conditions, once local corrosion initiates and propagates, the electrical and mechanical contact at the interface between Al current collector and active material deteriorate, inevitably leading to long-term discharge capacity loss. Additionally, the corrosion process is equivalent to a pseudo-platform during the charging step, prolonging the charging time. And the increase in corrosion current gradually reduces cathode delithiation. The accumulation of corrosion products also makes the interface impedance higher. All these lead to a reduction of current efficiency [27]. To ensure the longevity of LIBs, it is imperative to implement corresponding measures for protecting against corrosion on the Al current collector. Particularly, meticulous attention should be paid to controlling experimental variables and focusing on enhancing battery performance by optimizing Al stability. Admittedly, the most straightforward approach to mitigate corrosion is to operate LIBs in a stable environment (appropriate temperature and voltage below corrosion potential). However, it is a prevailing trend to develop high-voltage stable LIBs, and avoiding corrosion should not come at the expense of higher energy density [138,139]. Furthermore, advanced LIBs need to withstand harsh environment. In general, effective corrosion protection strategies can be categorized into two types: adjusting the electrolyte composition to form stable passivation layer or directly modifying Al to obtain an electrochemically more stable current collector. The utilization of diverse strategies presents distinct advantages. Our aim is to offer researchers valuable insights by elaborating on specific experimental cases, enabling them to select the most suitable protection strategy for complex actual conditions. 4.1 Efforts on electrolytes to avoid corrosion 4.1.1 Application of additives The essence of this strategy lies in adding an auxiliary lithium salt (e.g., LiPF6, LiBOB or LiDFOB, one with passivation ability) or a fluorinated compound to the dominant lithium salt in an electrolyte. This forms a secondary passivation layer during battery operation and reduces undesired corrosion [51,140,141]. Meanwhile, this approach preserves the merits of the main lithium salt, such as exceptional thermal and chemical stability and minimal susceptibility to water when using LiTFSI. Wang et al. [40] added LiPF6 to LiTFSI in EC + DME to inhibit corrosion by forming AlF3. And Kanamura et al. [64] even directly chose a small amount of HF as an additive to serve as the fluorine source for AlF3 formation. The application of this strategy is supported by more experimental details listed in Table S1. Chen et al. [80] achieved a stable Li|LFP battery with a LiTFSI-LiBOB electrolyte at 3.9 V, even at 60 °C. While the control group consisted of LiPF6 and LiTFSI electrolytes under identical conditions. The reduced current density in the CV curve reflects the effective passivation of Al surface, as shown in Fig. 12 (a). Fig. 12(b–e) confirms the improvement in long-cycle stability of batteries. At room temperature, the capacity of cells with both LiTFSI and LiPF6 electrolytes remains stable for up to 300 cycles before starting to decrease, which is attributed to the solubility of Al (TFSI)3 and the dissolution of iron from cathode caused by the hydrolysate HF, respectively. As the temperature rises to 60 °C, the thermal instability and hydrolysis of LiPF6 are exacerbated, leading to a rapid deterioration in cell performance.At this time, the advantage of LiTFSI at high temperature is revealed, and a longer cycle can be achieved if corrosion is restrained. These experimental results are consistent with the effects of anions, water, and temperature on corrosion discussed in Section 3, which are further reflected in battery performance. The addition of a small amount of LiBOB (x = 0.9) at room temperature can enhance the cycle stability up to 1000 cycles. While a more stable passivation layer is required at 60 °C, and excessive LiBOB content leads to capacity loss due to compromised electrical conductivity (x = 0.5). Therefore, the optimal ratio is LiTFSI0.6-LiBOB0.4. The passivation layer of LiBOB decomposes with increasing potential, resulting in a significant increase in both R ct and R sei of cells with LiTFSI0.6-LiBOB0.4 after 6 cycles, as evidenced by changes in impedance observed through EIS (Fig. 12f). Compared to LiPF6, this increase in interface impedance is disadvantageous to conductivity. However, the author demonstrated that the degree of current increase remains acceptable based on rate tests (0.2–5C). The synergistic effect of the combined use of multiple lithium salts affects not only the corrosion resistance of Al but also the anode interface. Zhang et al. [142] found that LiFSI enhances the rate performance of graphite anode in a LiPF6-based electrolyte. However, it is important to consider the ionic conductivity when determining the appropriate amount of LiFSI to add (Fig. 12g). Unfortunately, the inclusion of LiFSI results in a prolonged charging time for LFP cathode due to the high irreversible capacity caused by Al corrosion (Fig. 12h). Finally, the three combined salts of LiPF6, LiFSI and LiBOB were utilized for stabilizing full cell graphite|LFP. LiBOB reduces the corrosion induced by LiFSI, while LiFSI avoids excessive R sei caused by LiBOB. It can be seen that, compared to using a single salt, the mixing of lithium salts effectively mitigates their respective shortcomings while simultaneously combining individual advantages. And the majority of protective layer components are either boron-based or fluoro-based. 4.1.2 Regulation of solvents The solubility of Al-complexes varies among different solvents, with those having a low dielectric constant limiting the solubility of [Al(TFSI) x ](3− x )+. And certain solvents (e.g., nitrile) can also polymerize and adsorb onto Al surface to form a film that prevents the adsorption of corrosive particles. Furthermore, the incorporation of fluorinated solvent molecules has been demonstrated to serve as a fluorine source for the production of AlF3. Hence, the complete or partial replacement of solvents aids in forming a stable passivation layer that delays corrosion onset. Some related solvents have been discussed in Section 3.2. And the primary focus of this strategy is the enhancement of corrosion resistance and battery electrochemical performance in comparison to the widely used carbonate solvents, which are listed in Table S2. Yang et al. [36] changed the solvent of LiTFSI electrolyte from PC to PEGDME to reduce the diffusion of Al(TFSI)3 into solution. Kawamura et al. [86] selected a stable LiTFSI/MFA formula, and the battery performance of Li|LCO is even slightly better than that with traditional LiPF6 electrolyte. Similar to the cathodic protection method that uses sacrificial anodes, the preferential oxidation of solvent additives generates a protective mesophase during charging and inhibits the subsequent electrolyte decomposition. Zhu et al. [143] added tris (trimethylsilyl) phosphite (TMSPi), a silicon-containing phosphite, to LiPF6-carbonates electrolyte, resulting in a stable graphite|Li1.2Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13O2 cell. The preferential decomposition product of TMSPi covers the cathode material without directly impacting Al. However, it weakens crevice corrosion mediately by inhibiting the formation of HF, which provides a new perspective on corrosion protection (Fig. 13 a). The appearance of new characteristic peaks in the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectrum depicted in Fig. 13(b) confirms the decomposition of TMSPi. Furthermore, infrared testing is widely utilized for surface analysis of Al current collectors. The protection provided by mesophase improves the electrochemical performance of batteries, such as coulombic efficiency (close to 100%, Fig. 13c). It is noteworthy that a significant proportion of research has focused on the use of ILs with high thermal and electrochemical stability as solvent additives to mitigate Al corrosion, enhance LIB performance, and circumvent the issues of exorbitant cost, low-rate performance, and anode compatibility associated with ILs alone. Shangguan et al. [144] added varying concentrations of EMITFSI to a 1.0 M LiTFSI-based electrolyte determined that the optimal addition is 11% based on Al corrosion, as well as cycle and rate performance of Li|LFP. The efficacy of TMITFSI was proved by XPS, including the reduced peak intensity of C–O, C=O and Li2CO3 compared to the basic electrolyte, corresponding to a weaker oxidative decomposition on Al surface. Occasionally, the desired corrosion resistance may not be achieved simply by adding IL. Therefore, adjusting salt concentration simultaneously is necessary, which is also a strategy for anticorrosion proposed in next section. Rath et al. [145] investigated the optimal combination of salt concentration and PMPTFSI addition in a LiTFSI-based electrolyte. Raman spectroscopic analyses were performed to gain insight into the coordination structures of electrolyte. Fig. 13(d) shows various vibrational modes of TFSI− in the range of 720–780 cm−1. The solvent-separated state corresponds to free TFSI−. When TFSI− is coordinated with one or more cations, contact ion pair (CIP) and aggregate (AGG) are assembled. With an increase in LiTFSI concentration, the amount of free TFSI− decreases, indicating a decrease in the reaction activity with Al. And the best formula for salt concentration and IL addition was determined through rate tests, as shown in Fig. 13(e–g). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) spectrum (Fig. 13h) provides further evidence of the minimum R ct associated with this combination, which ensures the corrosion resistance of Al without excessively increasing interface impedance. 4.1.3 Development of highly concentrated electrolytes As mentioned in sections 3.1.2 and 4.1.2, increasing the concentration of lithium salt can augment anion coordination and restrict their mobility [146], thereby reducing the number of anions that interact with Al surface and avoiding corrosion risk. The implementation of concentrated electrolyte effectively mitigates the corrosion of LiTFSI, however, its high cost and viscosity must be taken into consideration for large-scale applications. Table S3 presents some experimental information related to this strategy. In light of the limitations posed by high concentration electrolyte, an increasing number of researchers are incorporating diluents into concentrated electrolytes while preserving the Li+ solvation sheath structure, thereby introducing the concept of ‘localized concentrated electrolyte’ [73,147]. This achieves the combined advantages of diluted electrolyte (e.g., high conductivity and low cost) and concentrated electrolyte (e.g., a large electrochemical stability window and good stability against Al current collector). It is obvious that the majority of research on such strategies has been directed towards imide-based anions, which lack the ability to passivate Al. In addition, it is emphasized that adjusting electrolyte composition can be achieved through a single method or a combination of the aforementioned methods. However, in pursuit of the current collector stability, it is imperative to consider the physical properties of the electrolyte such as electrical conductivity, thermal stability, and viscosity. The corresponding test methods, such as four-probe method or thermogravimetric analysis, have been verified by scholars during their exploration of optimal electrolyte formulas. And this paper primarily concentrates on the corrosion resistance of Al and the enhancement of battery performance through electrolyte adjustment, with limited discussion on electrolyte properties. 4.2 Preservation of aluminum from corrosion The direct modification of the Al current collector itself has gradually gained increasing scientific attention, yet it has not been studied as extensively as regulated electrolytes. This strategy is applicable to all types of anions. After all, for LiPF6-based electrolytes, the AlF3 layer is thin and heterogeneous, leaving room for improvement; and a more stable passivation layer is necessary to protect against HF erosion. While for low-concentration imide-based electrolytes, the development of an advanced Al current collector is undoubtedly more effective than tedious adjustment of electrolytes. The modified Al current collector should possess superior electrochemical stability while retaining its electron conduction function, which is of paramount importance. The relevant studies are presented in Table S4, which can be categorized into the surface treatment of Al and the protection of an artificial passivation layer. 4.2.1 Structured aluminum surface The surface treatment of Al aims to obtain a structured (acicular, porous) current collector through chemical or electrochemical modification, such as anodization, etching, or electrodeposition [148–151]. Jeong et al. [152] achieved highly ordered concave patterns on the Al surface through constant potential anodizing at various durations and subsequent acid treatment, as shown in Fig. 14 (a). Fig. 14(b) shows the X-Ray diffraction (XRD) verification of structured Al to ensure the absence of other impurities. The hexagonal honeycomb structure, which refers to the surface of anodized Al oxide dissolved by acid treatment, can be observed more intuitively in high magnification SEM images (Fig. 14c). The prolonged treatment duration results in a reduction of contact angle, an enhancement of adhesion, and renders it more suitable for LiCoO2 loading. The atomic force microscope (AFM) technique further provides roughness information, and is widely employed for monitoring changes in surface topography resulting from current collector corrosion (Fig. 14d). Fig. 14(e) shows the differences in total polarization resistance between 2nd and 20th cycles (ΔR p, R p: including resistance of active material cathode, Li anode, separator, and electrolyte) with the DOD (the depth of discharge), indicating an improvement in interface stability ofembossed Al. The structured current collector is not stabilized by the passivation layer of new components. Instead, a customized structure is employed to increase adhesion and contact area with the active material, reduce charge transfer resistance and battery internal impedance, thereby achieving long cycle stability and favorable rate performance. The utilization of 3D current collectors and even 3D electrodes in LIB anode measurements has been extensively investigated. These structures effectively suppress the formation of Li dendrites, minimize the diffusion distance of Li+ and electrons, and enhance specific power output [153–155]. However, considering corrosion electrochemistry aspects, it appears that the 3D nanostructured Al current collector is more susceptible to aggressive media immersion despite providing a high specific surface area. Further research in this regard is warranted. 4.2.2 In situ conversional passivation layer The artificial passivation layer of Al in organic electrolytes is limited by both corrosion resistance and electrical conductivity, which often contradict each other in the anticorrosion of water systems.This has resulted in a predominant focus of current research on following categories, classified based on material type and preparation process. The current collector itself undergoes a chemical conversion, during which the natural oxide layer Al2O3 is partially or completely transformed into other components following treatment. Meister et al. [133] treated the Al surface with high purity water at 100 °C to prepare a thicker Al-O film, and the cumulative charge test demonstrated a significant inhibition of anodic dissolution (Fig. 15 a and b). Chromate conversion coating (CCC) serves as a barrier to prevent direct exposure of Al to LiTFSI-based electrolytes, and the extended cycling only induces valence changes in Cr species without compromising the integrity of the passivation layer [45]. The objective of Yang et al. 's study is to develop an environmentally friendly molybdate conversion coating (MCC) that further enhances the stability of Al in LiPF6 (Fig. 15c). While scanning electrochemical microscope (SECM) reveals differences in current density at the micro-scale, and the current density of MCC-Al is significantly lower than that of pure Al (Fig. 15d) [156]. Similarly, Al coated with phosphate AlPO4 was obtained by immersing it in an AlPO4 solution until metallic luster disappeared, which also enhanced the capacity retention of NMC622 [47]. What these chemical conversion methods have in common is the precise regulation of reaction time to prevent excessively thick current collectors. Since a thicker passivation layer can enhance corrosion resistance, it may also impair electron conduction. 4.2.3 Constructed conductive barrier layer Carbon materials, which exhibit excellent electrical conductivity and outstanding electrochemical stability in organic electrolytes, are currently considered as promising candidates for corrosion protection of Al current collector. The carbon-coated Al was prepared through high-temperature chemical vapor deposition (CVD) using CH4 as C source [150,157]. The removal of the natural oxide layer decreases the interface impedance, while the agglomeration of carbon particles on the coating creates a complex pore system that enhances electrolyte wettability and reaction kinetics, thereby facilitating improved anchoring of active substances onto the current collector surface [158]. Although commercial carbon-coated Al foil has been widely used, it is not universally suitable for all systems or cut-off voltages. Yang et al. [31] have proposed that in LiPF6-based electrolyte (LB092), the porous C-Al passivation layer will result in a ‘small anode, large cathode’ effect once it breaks down at high potentials, leading to even worse cycle stability of batteries. With the popularity of graphene in the field of anticorrosion, an increasing number of researchers are exploring its potential as a protective layer for current collectors. Wang et al. [43] used plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) to grow multilayer graphene films (MLG) on Al foil directly at low temperature (without melting Al and omitting the transfer step), forming a conductive shield to prevent erosion particles from attacking Al3+ (Fig. 16 a). The XPS signal of C 1s indicates the dominant sp2 of as-synthesized MLG, while the relatively high ratio of C–O suggests efficient bonding between MLG and Al2O3, implying tight adhesion (Fig. 16b). And high-resolution cross-sectional TEM image and corresponding element mapping clearly indicate the absence of a discernible gap between MLG and Al. Kim et al. [159] attained optimal protection by regulating the quantity of graphene layers. Fig. 16(d) monitors the changes in LCO electrode before and after cycling, and no evidence of disintegration is observed for 3-Al (3 layers), including microcracks or detachment from Al. This is also reflected by the best capacity retention of batteries with 3-Al (Fig. 16e). The Tafel curve gives the corrosion kinetic parameters, showing that three-layer graphene has the lowest exchange current density in Fig. 16(f). However, dialectically, some researchers posit that non-ion selective graphene allows unbiased ion diffusion and facilitates the electrolyte submergence of high surface area, which may eventually lead to a relatively high corrosion rate of Al. Prabakar et al. [160] proposed that graphene oxide (GO) with surface electronegativity is more suitable, and electrostatic repulsion inhibits the proximity of PF6 − to Al (Fig. 16g). The GO-protected Al electrode loaded with LMO exhibits a lower voltage platform, thus resulting in a higher reversible capacity (energy density), as shown in Fig. 16(h). The corrosion of Al also impacts the self-discharge of cathode, with a delayed trend in self-discharge corresponding to a lighter corrosion (Fig. 16i). MXene is a novel two-dimensional material consisting of carbon, transition metals, and surface functional groups. It exhibits exceptional electrical conductivity, mechanical strength, and chemical stability, making it an ideal candidate for use as the conductive barrier for Al in LIBs. Yang et al. [31] utilized a simple self-assembly procedure to prepare an ultra-thin MXene layer on the Al surface, which comprehensively improved long-term and rate performance of the Li|NMC333 battery at a 4.5 V cut-off voltage (Fig. 17 a). In particular, scanning Kelvin probe (SKP) technology was employed to assess the electrochemical stability of current collectors. The narrow potential fluctuation range observed in MXene-Al indicates a uniform and thin passivation layer, while the heightened work function corresponds to robust oxidation resistance (Fig. 17b). The contribution of MXene layer to electron conduction was confirmed by conductive AFM (C-AFM). The position covered by Ti3C2 nanosheets shows a slightly higher current signal, which correlates well with the height map (Fig. 17c). Furthermore, the selectivity of terminal endows functional MXene with a novel perspective for combating current collector corrosion. The electrophoresis of DC power supply causes the electronegative MXene-Mo2CT x closely adhere to Al surface. The subsequent potentiostatic polarization replaces the unstable –OH with –F, and the specific proportion was verified by XPS analysis (Fig. 17d–e) [161]. The HOMO and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of MXene with different terminals in LiPF6 electrolyte were calculated to verify the antioxidation. The modest energy gaps exhibited by Mo2C(OH)2 and Mo2CF2 both reflect the exceptional electrical conductivity of MXene, with the relatively larger gap in Mo2CF2 indicating a preference for –F stability. Moreover, the higher HOMO of Mo2C(OH)2 is more vulnerable to electrolyte attack, meaning that the –F terminal is more resistant to oxidation (Fig. 17f). In Li|NMC333, the discharge capacity retention of cells with Mo2CF x -Al reaches up to 62.3% after 500 cycles at 0.5C, while that of pristine Al is only 7.0% (Fig. 17g).
