In addition, ceramic coatings and conductive polymers have also been utilized as artificial passivation layers in some studies [162–164], effectively inhibiting Al corrosion. However, ceramic coating induces an increased contact resistance, which may adversely impact cycling performance. The artificial passivation layer of Al current collector suitable for high-voltage stabilized LIB is still worthy of further exploration. 5 Conclusions and prospect With the advancement of high-voltage LIB technology, the issue of localized corrosion on the cathode Al current collector in organic electrolytes remains a bottleneck that continues to capture scientific attention. The onset of pitting corrosion in Al current collector is a spontaneous phenomenon that occurs upon exceeding the voltage threshold, and the stability of the passivation layer determines this maximum allowable voltage. And the crevice corrosion resulting from the accumulation of erosion particles with high local concentration at a moderate voltage is also acknowledged. Based on the diverse factors influencing corrosion, various protection strategies have been proposed to extend battery life, enhance capacity and power, and postpone self-discharge. However, the exploration in this field is not as extensive as that of high-voltage electrode materials and electrolytes. Therefore, future research should prioritize addressing the following issues shown in Fig. 18 . As a supplementary note, it is worth mentioning that LIBs, being the most mature secondary battery technology currently, have been able to summarize the current research and provide insights into the future based on a substantial amount of experimental data and case studies. We are more hopeful that this investigative approach to corrosion can be extended to other emerging battery technologies. For example, researchers are actively striving to enhance the energy density of low-cost sodium-ion batteries, where the interface issues of current collectors should be considered in the design of high-performance batteries. And in the case of lithium-sulfur batteries, the volume expansion and contraction of sulfur electrode materials during charge and discharge have also triggered contact issues between current collectors and electrodes, leading to corrosion. 5.1 In-depth exploration of corrosion mechanism The corrosion mechanism of Al current collector has not been fully elucidated due to the mutual interference of influencing factors. For instance, temperature, potential and electrolyte composition affect corrosion behavior, while changes in temperature and voltage also interfere with the properties of the electrolyte. Although we have individually analyzed each factor, it remains challenging to determine the precise quantitative impact of each factor in the actual service environment. We are of the opinion that utilizing advanced in-situ monitoring techniques can offer more direct and efficient evidence for the corrosion process, or unveil the initiation and propagation of corrosion on a more microscopic level, thereby enabling a deeper understanding of the corrosion mechanism. Currently, the majority of corrosion models focus on pitting corrosion, with limited research on crevice corrosion that takes into account active material properties. Further investigation is required to examine the impact of electrode material porosity or thickness on corrosion, particularly in light of the current emergence of advanced high-voltage cathode materials. This should be conducted while ensuring battery performance remains unaffected and avoiding cracks. Theoretical calculations can be employed to simulate this process. And the corrosion mechanism exploration should more accurately replicate the operational conditions of batteries, including high temperatures and mechanical loads. Additionally, the methodology of mechanism exploration in conventional electrolytes (e.g., 1 M LiPF6 in organic carbonates) is equally applicable to novel electrolytes. Multi-component lithium salts or ionic liquids are emerging areas of research interest, and their impact on current collector stability should not be disregarded. 5.2 Corrosion evaluation for battery performance The corrosion deterioration of Al current collector is merely one among many forms of battery failure, and most studies observe the consequences of corrosion inhibition on electrochemical performance improvement while controlling variables as much as possible. Therefore, assessing the impact of corrosion on the overall battery failure process amidst numerous interrelated factors poses a challenging yet crucial task. It would be highly advantageous to employ in-situ/in-operando monitoring technology in order to distill the impact of current collector corrosion on the electrochemical performance of full cells. Up to now, there is a dearth of specific evaluation criteria for Al corrosion under actual operating conditions of LIBs, leading researchers to potentially incomplete or inaccurate verification of corrosion and corrosion resistance across various electrolyte formulations. We recommend that relevant studies should encompass the electrochemical behavior of current collectors in electrolytes, interface observation, changes in physical or chemical properties of current collectors or electrolytes after applying corrosion inhibition strategies, as well as comprehensive verification of battery electrochemical performance. 5.3 Future corrosion suppression strategies The study of corrosion protection for Al in LIBs is a prominent research area nowadays. The strategy of electrolyte composition adjustment has reached a relatively mature stage, while the research and development of novel additives is still ongoing. The majority of the newly developed additives possess a composition structure that exhibits passivation capabilities, rendering them impervious to properties such as electrical conductivity. In addition, greater emphasis should be placed on exploring novel preparation methods or surface treatments for the current collector (not limited to Al), which are currently not fully investigated. For example, it is worth considering whether a 3D cathode current collector can achieve high wettability for aggressive electrolytes at high potential while maintaining electrochemical stability. Exploring a suitable multi-system protection coating for current collector is currently the most popular approach, as it is more direct and effective than modifying the electrolyte formula. Various novel materials for protective coatings are awaiting validation, which are expected to enhance the electrochemical stability while maintaining the intrinsic functionality of current collector. For instance, an artificial passivation layer that stabilizes Al in low concentrated LiTFSI-carbonate electrolytes undoubtedly propels high-voltage LIBs to new heights. Nevertheless, the trade-off between accessibility, cost-effectiveness and functionality of these coatings will ultimately determine their practical application. And it is crucial to emphasize that the implementation of corresponding proposed methods must undergo rigorous verification, as outlined in Section 5.2. Shanglin Yang is currently pursuing a doctorate degree at Beihang University under the guidance of Professor Songmei Li and Bin Li. His research focuses on the corrosion and protection of cathode aluminum current collector in lithium-ion battery. Jinyan Zhong received her PhD from Beihang University in 2019 and joined the School of Materials Science and Engineering as an associate researcher. She mainly engaged in the corrosion science of aerospace materials and equipment, advanced protection technologies for alloys, as well as nano functional materials and technologies. Songmei Li obtained her PhD from Beihang University in 2004 and currently holds the position of a professor in the School of Materials Science and Engineering. She is also an executive director of the Chinese Society for Corrosion and Protection. Her research interests encompass materials electrochemistry, new energy materials and the corrosion and protection of metals. Bin Li received his PhD from Beihang University in 2016 and currently serves as an associate professor in the School of Materials Science and Engineering. He undertook the National Natural Science Foundation Youth Project. His research interests cover new energy materials and devices, including lithium-sulfur batteries, lithium metal batteries, solid-state batteries and electrochemistry for energy storage.

coredata.dc:description: With the large-scale service of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), their failures have attracted significant attentions. While the decay of active materials is the primary cause for LIB failures, the degradation of auxiliary materials, such as current collector corrosion, should not be disregarded. Therefore, it is necessary to conduct a comprehensive review in this field. In this review, from the perspectives of electrochemistry and materials, we systematically summarize the corrosion behavior of aluminum cathode current collector and propose corresponding countermeasures. Firstly, the corrosion type is clarified based on the properties of passivation layers in different organic electrolyte components. Furthermore, a thoroughgoing analysis is presented to examine the impact of various factors on aluminum corrosion, including lithium salts, organic solvents, water impurities, and operating conditions. Subsequently, strategies for electrolyte and protection layer employed to suppress corrosion are discussed in detail. Lastly and most importantly, we provide insights and recommendations to prevent corrosion of current collectors, facilitate the development of advanced current collectors and the implementation of next-generation high-voltage stable LIBs.
